title: Computational scientist
text:
A computational scientist is a person skilled in <a href="scientific%20computing">scientific computing</a>. This person is usually a <a href="scientist">scientist</a>, a <a href="statistician">statistician</a>, an <a href="applied%20mathematician">applied mathematician</a>, or an <a href="engineer">engineer</a> who applies <a href="high-performance%20computing">high-performance computing</a> and sometimes <a href="cloud%20computing">cloud computing</a> in different ways to advance the state-of-the-art in his respective applied discipline; <a href="physics">physics</a>, <a href="chemistry">chemistry</a>, <a href="social%20sciences">social sciences</a> and so forth. Thus scientific computing has increasingly influenced many areas such as <a href="economics">economics</a>, <a href="biology">biology</a>, <a href="law">law</a>, and <a href="medicine">medicine</a> to name a few. Because a computational scientist's work is generally applied to <a href="science">science</a> and other disciplines, they are not necessarily trained in <a href="computer%20science">computer science</a> specifically, though concepts of computer science are often used. Computational scientists are typically <a href="researchers">researchers</a> at <a href="University">academic universities</a>, national labs, or <a href="Technology%20company">tech companies</a>.
One of the tasks of a computational scientist is to analyze large amounts of data, often from <a href="astrophysics">astrophysics</a> or related fields, as these can often generate huge amounts of data. Computational scientists often have to clean up and calibrate the data to a usable form for an effective analysis. Computational scientists are also tasked with creating artificial data through <a href="Computer%20simulation">computer models</a> and simulations.
